It’s my experience that the ultimate mindset to cultivate and strive for every single day in order to maximize relationships, happiness and productivity is to be: loving, realistic and hardworking. That’s the trifecta.

The reason to deliberately do hard things is so that when non-self-elected challenges arrive (and they will), you can tell yourself: “I don’t know how this is all going to turn out, but I am certain I can do hard things.” Don’t self-injure. But doing hard things is always worthwhile.

You don't have to wait 90-120min after waking to consume caffeine but if you regularly experience an afternoon crash in energy, doing so can help offset that. If you exercise first thing in the morning, caffeine can go first; no need to wait but be sure to hydrate well too.

For many, a thorough reset of afternoon mental & physical energy is best achieved by a 10-20min NSDR (rather than a nap or more caffeine) as it improves rather than degrades night time sleep which = the essential reset.

link_preview_attachment.title: R E V E R I - The World's Most Trusted Self-Hypnosis App

post.caption: The new reveri app is very useful for science/clinically-supported hypnosis for sleep, focus, stress relief etc. They have a zero-cost hypnotizability test. Hypnosis basically = “meditation to solve a specific problem via neuroplasticity”. Reveri.com

A new study found that just one 5min deliberate cold exposure session (20C/68F; which isn’t that cold!) elevated mood & reduced negative affect & changed resting state connectivity in brain networks associated with positive affect (for the “better”). https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36829490/

I still recommend that if people are going to do deliberate cold exposure that they not do it in the six hours after hypertrophy or strength training, as it can prevent some of those adaptations. At other times, it should be fine. And, of course, no obligation to do deliberate  cold exposure!

When we think of dopamine as “reinforcing” (of thoughts & behaviors) as opposed to dopamine being “rewarding”, the basis of many maladaptive choices, trauma-patterns, addictions etc. become clear(er). That won’t resolve them but it is a key first step. What gets reinforced gets repeated & eventually becomes reflexive.

In a recent class I taught @stanford we read & applied data-supported tools on how to learn/neuroplasticity. Among the most effective tools: periodically thinking back on material *in a structured way* & figuring out where your gaps in knowledge remain, reread & repeat. It outperforms note taking. 
(But also take notes).

The best structure is to try and make it linear. That is, try not to let your mind skip around between different components of the learn material. That process can come later. The first step is to get mastery over the concepts in a start to finish way. For the type of material that requires problem sets obviously you’ll need to do the problem sets.

link_preview_attachment.title: HOW TO IMPROVE (FASTER) THROUGH EFFORT• - I’ve been researching mindsets, and it’s a fascinating literature. Many people have heard of the so-called growth mindset, which is the idea that we can improve our intelligence and our abilities through effort. However, despite many people acknowledging the existence of growth mindset it’s often hard for people to adopt, especially when they are not getting the results they want.  - Recent work published in Nature, shows that combining a growth mindset with the idea that “stress is enhancing of performance” mindset, is one of the most effective ways to improve performance- in essentially any and everything.  - What’s incredible about the study is that the combined mindsets mentioned above leads to improved physiology and performance in a lot of different domains, and is likely to be the consequence of neuroplasticity— literally the rewiring of brain circuits. - I’ll be doing an entire episode of the Huberman Lab podcast about mindsets very soon but meanwhile it felt too important to not share now. I highly encourage people to cultivate a growth mindset and also to *think about the stress response as the body‘s natural response to enhance our cognitive and physical abilities*.  — Keep those both in mind even when you’re not getting the results you want and start to analyze the results with the same perspective. The data all say that if you do, great improvement resides just around the corner… - Meanwhile, please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post, and as always thank you for your interest in science!  - @hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @societyforneuroscience @cellpress  - #neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #neuroplasticity #brain #growthmindset #stress #ability #effort

post.caption: Amazing research on mindsets and how to improve. Having a growth mindset is necessary, but not sufficient. You also have to change your attitude about stress. Fortunately, this is possible.

White noise as background to increase focus during work bouts, or 40Hz binaural beats— both of which by the way are available at zero cost online via YouTube, apps like Brainwave etc., are among the more useful data-supported tools for increasing focus. They won’t cure ADHD but they can assist focus in meaningful ways.

link_preview_attachment.title: How Andrew Huberman Got America to Care About Science

post.caption: Thank you @time for this article about the origins, mission and future of the Huberman Lab podcast. https://time.com/6290594/andrew-hubman-lab-podcast-interview/

No discussion of hacks, supplements etc should ever be considered ￼until we are tending to:
THE 5 CORE PILLARS OF MENTAL & PHYSICAL HEALTH & PERFORMANCE, every 24hrs. 
1) sufficient amounts of quality sleep
2) quality nutrition, meaning mostly unprocessed or minimally processed nutrients
3) exercise and movement: both cardiovascular and resistance training, although not necessarily on same days
4) sunlight, viewed by our eyes especially in the morning
5) healthy, trusted social connections

Here on @threadsapp but really every day, get sunlight in your eyes as early in the day as possible, ideally while facing east; and again in the afternoon/evening. This is known to improve daytime mood, focus and alertness and nighttime sleep via established mechanisms. Don’t stare at the sun. Blink as needed. But do it.

link_preview_attachment.title: Dr. Jeffrey Goldberg: How to Improve Your Eye Health & Offset Vision Loss - Huberman Lab

post.caption: This Huberman Lab episode with the Chair of Ophthalmology at Stanford School of Medicine, Jeffrey Goldberg MD, PhD, is a must listen for anyone wanting to maintain or improve their vision and for parents with kids that use screens >1hr/day. https://hubermanlab.com/dr-jeffrey-goldberg-how-to-improve-your-eye-health-and-offset-vision-loss/

Understanding mechanisms is what allows us flexibility, as opposed to rigidity, of protocols and their implementation under different conditions. Mechanisms also reinforce the rational basis — the “why” for the “to-dos.” Also, biology is really cool.

I’m researching growth mindset for an upcoming Huberman Lab episode, and I must say it is far more interesting literature than I ever anticipated. I’m also realizing that it’s badly misunderstood by the general public— due to the typical coverage (whereas the science is superb). For instance, growth mindset seems to effectively change performance best when both teachers and students adopt it and when it’s combined with a firm understanding of stress biology. Excited to share more soon.

Happy 4th of July! Celebrate your independence but realize that none of us are independent from the impact of our circadian biology. So be sure to get some sunlight in your eyes as early in the day as possible to maintain/set circadian entrainment to the day-night cycle.
